comments:
Topics covered include: linear algebra; vectors, matrices, systems of linear
equations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors; vector calculus: functions of several variables,
vector fields, line and surface integrals, Green's, Stokes' and divergence theorems;
differential equations: series solutions of ordinary differential equations, Laplace
transforms and systems of ordinary differential equations.
Students generally found the course to be very useful. They also found the
material to be “pretty dense,” “technical,” and “difficult,” but generally felt that they got
a lot out of the course.
Virtually all students really raved about Professor Jankowski. He was described
as “funny” and “down-to-earth.” Many appreciated how available he was after class and
his prompt and thorough follow-ups to student inquiries. They also felt that he was
“engaging,” “well-organized,” and “made lectures interesting.”
This course was recommended for anyone who plans on taking any more upperlevel
math classes. Students also mentioned that this was a very well-done class even for
non-math majors.

This class covers linear algebra: vectors, matrices, systems of linear equations,
eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Later it merges into vector calculus: functions of several
variables, vector fields, line and surface integrals, Green's, Stokes' and divergence
theorems. It also covers series solutions of ordinary differential equations, Laplace
transforms and systems of ordinary differential equations. This course uses symbolic
manipulation and graphics software.
Overall, students felt that the class could benefit from more examples. They felt
that the lectures were too theoretical. In addition, some felt that some of the concepts
covered were “tedious and unnecessary.”
Students overall were pleased with Professor Lipsky’s teaching style. They found
that he was “very clear and organized” and he always “prepared well” for class. Most
students felt that Professor Lipsky really “understood the foundations and roots of
mathematics.” He was also successful in helping the students understand math in a more
conceptual manner. However, some students thought that Professor Lipsky should teach
less out of the textbook.
This class is recommended for both majors and non-majors. The prerequisite for
this class is MATH 114.

MATH240 offers an introduction to Linear Algebra and further coverage of
vector calculus, building upon MATH114. Concepts include vectors, matrices, systems of
linear equations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, functions of several variables, vector
fields, line and surface integrals, Green’s, Stokes’, divergence theorems, series solutions
of ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms and systems of ordinary differential
equations.
Most students described the class as very good overall. Many thought that
concepts covered throughout the semester were quite interesting.
Professor Gluck received mixed reviews. Some students described him as
“wonderful,” “passionate,” and “engaging,” but there were an equal number of students
who were dissatisfied with Profesor Gluck’s communication abilities, likely because of
the noted rushed coverage of vector calculus concepts at the end of the course. In general,
students felt that Professor Gluck put a great deal of care and effort into teaching, but fell
short in coverage of certain areas.
Engineers and students studying highly quantitative majors primarily take the
course. The class is quite challenging requiring a lot of time and work. Many students felt
that exams were much more difficult than expected. To do well, students should have a
thorough understanding of lecture material and assigned practice problems.
